awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Enhanced Electronic Cooling via 3D Printing from Additive Laser Fabrication of Heat Removal Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to enable better cooling for more efficient and powerful computing.  This technology development and commercialization project will investigate the potential benefit of 3D printing metal fins directly onto silicon to enable a 10X improvement in cooling compared to standard existing technologies.  This technology may enable faster and higher power computing, especially for supercomputers conducting high demand processes, such as training artificial intelligence systems. The research objective is to demonstrate a performance benefit resulting from the optimization of the printing process, mechanical bonding/reliability, and the heat sink design.  The education objective is to train a postdoctoral and student team in the essentials of entrepreneurship and leadership through industry mentorship and participation in Binghamton University’s XCEED and regional I-Corps program.  Participation will be broadened by inclusion of an LSAMP summer student in the research, and having the student and postdoc team lead a seminar explaining their innovation and entrepreneurial quest at our campus LSAMP’s seminar series.  

The proposed project focuses on translating research on laser printing a molten metal alloy, called Sn3Ag4Ti, on a silicon substrate into a minimum viable product for demonstration to potential development and strategic partners. The process includes depositing a thin powder layer of Sn3Ag4Ti onto silicon and exposing the areas where cooling fins are desired to laser heating. Subsequent layers of copper are then deposited onto this layer to form high-aspect ratio cooling fins using selective laser melting. The rapid laser heating forms thin silicide and intermetallic films at the interface. The manufacture of the entire fin assembly using selective laser melting will be researched, specifically how to deposit high thermal conductivity copper metal onto the Sn3Ag4Ti layer.  We will also measure the interfacial mechanical properties and thermal cyclability of the device, which are critical to electronic packaging reliability. The design of the heat sink at high heat fluxes, expected in the next generation of packages, will be optimized using neural network techniques. Our research will solve key translational challenges by refining the processing method, demonstrating long-term mechanical reliability, and optimizing the printed heat sink for minimal thermal resistance at high heat fluxes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The PFI-TT: Enhanced Electronic Cooling via 3D Printing from Additive Laser Fabrication of Heat Removal Devices project has made significant advances in both the science of electronics cooling and the practical application of this technology. Our work has centered on developing a novel additive manufacturing method that directly prints cooling structures onto silicon chips, eliminating the need for traditional thermal interface materials. This approach not only streamlines the cooling process but also dramatically improves energy and computational efficiency.

Key Technological Breakthroughs
We successfully demonstrated, for the first time, the direct printing of cooling devices onto the silicon die of commercial microprocessors such as the Intel i7 and Nvidia Jetson. By using a unique laser raster strategy and a printed interlayer that forms a robust silicide bond with the silicon, we created an integrated cooling system that delivers up to 12 times the cooling efficiency per unit cooling area compared to conventional immersion boiling enhancement designs.  

Broader Impacts and Intellectual Merit
The innovative cooling technique developed through this project addresses one of the most pressing challenges in electronics: managing ever-increasing heat generation. Improved cooling leads to lower operating temperatures, which in turn translate into energy savings, reduced CO₂ emissions, and decreased electronic waste.

The project has also enriched the scientific community’s understanding of materials science and additive manufacturing. By integrating laser powder bed fusion with new interlayer chemistry, we have paved the way for further innovations in embedded cooling technology. 

Industry Collaboration and Technology Transfer

Our outcomes have strong implications for commercial applications. In collaboration with industry partners, we have shared our findings through multiple channels including conference presentations, journal publications, and patent filings. The patent application for "Thermal-safe additive manufacturing for electronics" (Application No. 18/318,670) represents a critical step towards bringing this technology to market. Additionally, our efforts are spurring the formation of a spinout company, which is now gearing up to commercialize the technology. 

Educational and Workforce Development
Beyond the technical achievements, this project has played a pivotal role in training and mentoring the next generation of engineers and scientists. Graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and undergraduates have been actively involved in developing and testing the technology, gaining invaluable hands-on experience in advanced manufacturing and thermal management. Participation in national entrepreneurial programs and I-Corps training has further equipped our team with the skills necessary for technology commercialization, ensuring a lasting impact on workforce development in the fields of electronics cooling and additive manufacturing. The PI has also integrated activities related to this project into undergraduate heat transfer and additive manufacturing.


Last Modified: 03/21/2025
Modified by: Scott N Schiffres

Image
  • By additively manufacturing cooling devices directly onto the backside of a silicon chip, we have a cooling device with an areal footprint less than 3% commercial immersion cooling cold plates. Additionally, this technology removes the bottleneck of thermal interface materials.
    Scott Schiffres
    Copyrighted
    Scott N Schiffres
    Directly printed cooling structures on silicon chip efficiently cools microprocessor
